elements.content: Two In-based metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have been designed and synthesized by the reaction of 3-phenylpyridine polycarboxylic ligands and In3+ cations: In3L1 4·(CH3NH2CH3)3 (H3L1 = 5-(3′,5′-dicarboxylphenyl)­nicotic acid; 1) and In2L2 2(CH3COO)2·(CH3)2NH2·(CH3)3NH·H2O (H3L2 = 3-(2,4-dicarboxylphenyl)-6-carboxylpyridine; 2). Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis indicates that the In3+ centers in 1 are all coordinated by eight oxygen atoms from four carboxylate groups, resulting in a 3D framework with two different channels A and B with sizes of 14.4 × 8.75 and 7.24 × 6.7 Å2, respectively. In 2, each In3+ center was coordinated by six carboxylate oxygen atoms and a pyridine N atom, forming a 2D layerlike structure. These 2D layers are further fused together via electrostatic interactions into a 3D supramolecular framework, showing two kinds of channels A′ and B′ with pore sizes of 5.25 × 9.69 and 4.29 × 8.66 Å2, respectively. In this work, the coordination of N to the In3+ center in 2 was first achieved by regulating carboxyl sites in 3-phenylpyridine, thus increasing the stability of the In-based MOF. A detailed structural study reveals that the formation of In–N bonds promotes the conversion of the 3D framework of 1 into the supramolecular structure of 2. However, the supramolecular structure in 2 is more stable in air and methanol in comparison to the 3D framework of 1, confirming the important role of In–N bonds in enhancing the framework stability. Thus, 2 could be used as a stable adsorbent to selectively capture CO2 from a CO2/N2 mixture, while 1 broke down sharply in air and in a methanol solution.
elements.clean_text: Two In-based metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been designed and synthesized by the reaction of 3-phenylpyridine polycarboxylic ligands and In3+ cations: In3L1 4⋅(CH3NH2CH3)3 (H3L1 = 5-(3',5'-dicarboxylphenyl)nicotic acid; 1) and In2L2 2(CH3COO)2⋅(CH3)2NH2⋅(CH3)3NH⋅H2O (H3L2 = 3-(2,4-dicarboxylphenyl)-6-carboxylpyridine; 2). Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis indicates that the In3+ centers in 1 are all coordinated by eight oxygen atoms from four carboxylate groups, resulting in a 3D framework with two different channels A and B with sizes of 14.4 × 8.75 and 7.24 × 6.7 Å2, respectively. In 2, each In3+ center was coordinated by six carboxylate oxygen atoms and a pyridine N atom, forming a 2D layerlike structure. These 2D layers are further fused together via electrostatic interactions into a 3D supramolecular framework, showing two kinds of channels A' and B' with pore sizes of 5.25 × 9.69 and 4.29 × 8.66 Å2, respectively. In this work, the coordination of N to the In3+ center in 2 was first achieved by regulating carboxyl sites in 3-phenylpyridine, thus increasing the stability of the In-based MOF. A detailed structural study reveals that the formation of In-N bonds promotes the conversion of the 3D framework of 1 into the supramolecular structure of 2. However, the supramolecular structure in 2 is more stable in air and methanol in comparison to the 3D framework of 1, confirming the important role of In-N bonds in enhancing the framework stability. Thus, 2 could be used as a stable adsorbent to selectively capture CO2 from a CO2/N2 mixture, while 1 broke down sharply in air and in a methanol solution.

elements.content: Two In-based MOFs with different structures were obtained by adjusting the position of carboxyl groups in 3-phenylpyridine, which confirmed nitrogen coordination to the In3+ center playing an important role in dramatically enhancing the stability of In-based MOFs.
elements.clean_text: Two In-based MOFs with different structures were obtained by adjusting the position of carboxyl groups in 3-phenylpyridine, which confirmed nitrogen coordination to the In3+ center playing an important role in dramatically enhancing the stability of In-based MOFs.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), a great class of porous crystalline materials constructed from a metal cation/cluster and a polydentate organic ligand, have received considerable interest in the past few decades. Because of their easily adjustable compositions and structures, they possess various potential applications, such as gas storage and separation, catalysis, and photoelectric devices. In this field, a number of methods have been proposed to design and synthesize novel and multifunctional MOFs by decorating organic ligands and inorganic metal cation/cluster based nodes. One significant trend in synthesizing novel and multifunctional MOFs is the use of polydentate ligands containing both carboxylate units and N-heterocyclic rings, which greatly contribute to the construction of MOFs with high stability. Apart from organic linkers, metal cations with different oxidation states also play an important role in the construction of stable MOFs. As is well-known, most of the divalent transition-metal (TM2+) ions are usually coordinated by O- or N-donor ligands, forming four- to six-coordinate environments. In this process, TM2+-N MOFs are usually more stable than TM2+-carboxylate MOFs. Tetravalent and trivalent TM cations, such as Zr4+ and In3+, usually tend to form MOFs with TM-O coordination modes by forming six- to eight-coordinate environments. However, in comparison to the number of TM2+- and Zr4+-based MOFs, In3+-based MOFs are comparatively fewer in number in literature reports. In this field, the In3+ ions were used to react with organic di-, tri-, and tetracarboxylic ligands, resulting in several In-based 2D and 3D frameworks, which have been widely used for gas separation, pollutant removal, and catalytic reactions. Among these structures, it could be found that most of the In3+ centers tend to coordinate with carboxylate oxygen atoms, although several ligands contain N and S heteroatoms. To date, the design and synthesis of In-based framework materials are still in their infancy and represent a promising way to construct stable MOFs for various applications, especially for introducing polydentate ligands with both carboxylate and N-heterocyclic rings into the In-MOFs to promote the formation of In–N bonds.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), a great class of porous crystalline materials constructed from a metal cation/cluster and a polydentate organic ligand, have received considerable interest in the past few decades. Because of their easily adjustable compositions and structures, they possess various potential applications, such as gas storage and separation, catalysis, and photoelectric devices. In this field, a number of methods have been proposed to design and synthesize novel and multifunctional MOFs by decorating organic ligands and inorganic metal cation/cluster based nodes. One significant trend in synthesizing novel and multifunctional MOFs is the use of polydentate ligands containing both carboxylate units and N-heterocyclic rings, which greatly contribute to the construction of MOFs with high stability. Apart from organic linkers, metal cations with different oxidation states also play an important role in the construction of stable MOFs. As is well-known, most of the divalent transition-metal (TM2+) ions are usually coordinated by O- or N-donor ligands, forming four- to six-coordinate environments. In this process, TM2+-N MOFs are usually more stable than TM2+-carboxylate MOFs. Tetravalent and trivalent TM cations, such as Zr4+ and In3+, usually tend to form MOFs with TM-O coordination modes by forming six- to eight-coordinate environments. However, in comparison to the number of TM2+- and Zr4+-based MOFs, In3+-based MOFs are comparatively fewer in number in literature reports. In this field, the In3+ ions were used to react with organic di-, tri-, and tetracarboxylic ligands, resulting in several In-based 2D and 3D frameworks, which have been widely used for gas separation, pollutant removal, and catalytic reactions. Among these structures, it could be found that most of the In3+ centers tend to coordinate with carboxylate oxygen atoms, although several ligands contain N and S heteroatoms. To date, the design and synthesis of In-based framework materials are still in their infancy and represent a promising way to construct stable MOFs for various applications, especially for introducing polydentate ligands with both carboxylate and N-heterocyclic rings into the In-MOFs to promote the formation of In-N bonds.

elements.content: Herein, two organic linkers with the same composition () were used to construct new In-based MOFs with different structures by adjusting the position of the carboxyl groups in 3-phenylpyridine. All of the In3+ centers in 1 are coordinated by eight carboxylate oxygen atoms, exhibiting a 3D framework with two different channels with sizes of 14.4 × 8.75 and 7.24 × 6.7 Å2, respectively. In 2, an In3+ center was coordinated by six carboxylate oxygen atoms and a pyridine N atom to form a 2D layerlike structure, which was fused together via electrostatic interactions into a 3D supramolecular framework. It is surprising that the supramolecular structure in 2 is more stable in air and methanol in comparison to the 3D framework in 1 due to the formation of In–N bonds. Thus, 2 could be used as a stable adsorbent to selectively capture CO2 from a CO2/N2 mixture, while 1 broke down sharply in air and the exchanged solvents.
elements.clean_text: Herein, two organic linkers with the same composition () were used to construct new In-based MOFs with different structures by adjusting the position of the carboxyl groups in 3-phenylpyridine. All of the In3+ centers in 1 are coordinated by eight carboxylate oxygen atoms, exhibiting a 3D framework with two different channels with sizes of 14.4 × 8.75 and 7.24 × 6.7 Å2, respectively. In 2, an In3+ center was coordinated by six carboxylate oxygen atoms and a pyridine N atom to form a 2D layerlike structure, which was fused together via electrostatic interactions into a 3D supramolecular framework. It is surprising that the supramolecular structure in 2 is more stable in air and methanol in comparison to the 3D framework in 1 due to the formation of In-N bonds. Thus, 2 could be used as a stable adsorbent to selectively capture CO2 from a CO2/N2 mixture, while 1 broke down sharply in air and the exchanged solvents.

elements.content: H3L1 (10 mg, 0.03 mmol) and In­(NO3)3 ·4H2O (11 mg, 0.03 mmol) were added to a DMF (2 mL) solution containing glacial acetic acid (100 μL). Then, the mixture was stirred for 1/2 h at room temperature and placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. Subsequently, the solution was heated at 150 °C and maintained at that temperature for 72 h. Next, the mixture was slowly cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C h–1. Colorless crystals were harvested by centrifugation in a yield of 42% based on In. IR (KBr pellet) for 1: ν 1620 (s), 1360 (s), 1300 (w), 1246 (s), 1047 (w), 1019 (s), 938 (m), 863 (m), 841 (m), 783 (s), 721 (s), 699 (s), 663 (m), 442 (m) cm–1.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis of In3L1 4⋅(CH3NH2CH3)3 (1)

H3L1 (10 mg, 0.03 mmol) and In(NO3)3 ⋅4H2O (11 mg, 0.03 mmol) were added to a DMF (2 mL) solution containing glacial acetic acid (100 μL). Then, the mixture was stirred for 1/2 h at room temperature and placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. Subsequently, the solution was heated at 150 °C and maintained at that temperature for 72 h. Next, the mixture was slowly cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C h-1. Colorless crystals were harvested by centrifugation in a yield of 42% based on In. IR (KBr pellet) for 1: ν 1620 (s), 1360 (s), 1300 (w), 1246 (s), 1047 (w), 1019 (s), 938 (m), 863 (m), 841 (m), 783 (s), 721 (s), 699 (s), 663 (m), 442 (m) cm-1.

elements.content: H3L2 (8 mg, 0.028 mmol) and In­(NO3)3 ·4H2O (20 mg, 0.053 mmol) were added to a DMF (2 mL) solution containing glacial acetic acid (200 μL); this mixture was stirred for 1/2 h at room temperature and placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. After it was heated at 130 °C for 72 h, the mixture was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C h–1. Colorless block crystals were harvested in a yield of 73% based on In. IR (KBr pellet) for 2: ν 1667 (s), 1367 (s), 1255 (w), 1097 (m), 1026 (w), 908 (w), 778 (s), 750 (w), 704 (m), 662 (m), 450 (m) cm–1.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of In2L2 2(CH3COO)2⋅(CH3)2NH2⋅(CH3)3NH⋅H2O (2)

H3L2 (8 mg, 0.028 mmol) and In(NO3)3 ⋅4H2O (20 mg, 0.053 mmol) were added to a DMF (2 mL) solution containing glacial acetic acid (200 μL); this mixture was stirred for 1/2 h at room temperature and placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. After it was heated at 130 °C for 72 h, the mixture was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C h-1. Colorless block crystals were harvested in a yield of 73% based on In. IR (KBr pellet) for 2: ν 1667 (s), 1367 (s), 1255 (w), 1097 (m), 1026 (w), 908 (w), 778 (s), 750 (w), 704 (m), 662 (m), 450 (m) cm-1.

elements.content: Reaction of H3L1 with In­(NO3)3 in DMF at 150 °C affords colorless crystals of 1. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis shows that 1 crystallizes in an orthorhombic crystal system with Fddd space group (Table S1). As shown in a, one crystallographic asymmetric unit of 1 contains a H3L1 ligand and two In3+ ions. It is worth mentioning that the In3+ center tends to combine with carboxylate O atoms; thus, each In3+ ion is surrounded by eight carboxylate O atoms from four different H3L1 ligands (b). Each carboxylate group binds to the In3+ center via a bidentate-chelate mode, and the In–O bond lengths are in the range of 2.148(6)–2.449(11) Å. Also, each L1 in 1 coordinates with three In3+ ions through three carboxylate groups, thus generating a (3,4)-connected 3D framework with two different channels A and B with sizes of 14.4 × 8.75 and 7.24 × 6.7 Å2, respectively (c,d and Figures S1–S4). In the synthesis of 1, although acetic acid does not exist in the final product, it plays a key role in the formation of 1 as a pH value regulator. In the absence of acetic acid, compound 1 could not be obtained under similar conditions. It can also be seen that the N atom disconnects from the In3+ center, which may be a potential coordination site for further enhancing the stability of the MOFs by the formation of In–N bonds.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Structure

Reaction of H3L1 with In(NO3)3 in DMF at 150 °C affords colorless crystals of 1. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis shows that 1 crystallizes in an orthorhombic crystal system with Fddd space group (Table S1). As shown in a, one crystallographic asymmetric unit of 1 contains a H3L1 ligand and two In3+ ions. It is worth mentioning that the In3+ center tends to combine with carboxylate O atoms; thus, each In3+ ion is surrounded by eight carboxylate O atoms from four different H3L1 ligands (b). Each carboxylate group binds to the In3+ center via a bidentate-chelate mode, and the In-O bond lengths are in the range of 2.148(6)-2.449(11) Å. Also, each L1 in 1 coordinates with three In3+ ions through three carboxylate groups, thus generating a (3,4)-connected 3D framework with two different channels A and B with sizes of 14.4 × 8.75 and 7.24 × 6.7 Å2, respectively (c,d and Figures S1-S4). In the synthesis of 1, although acetic acid does not exist in the final product, it plays a key role in the formation of 1 as a pH value regulator. In the absence of acetic acid, compound 1 could not be obtained under similar conditions. It can also be seen that the N atom disconnects from the In3+ center, which may be a potential coordination site for further enhancing the stability of the MOFs by the formation of In-N bonds.

elements.content: (a) Asymmetric unit of 1. (b) Coordination mode of In3+. (c) Ball and stick and (d) space filling representations of the 3D structure of 1. The H atoms are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Asymmetric unit of 1. (b) Coordination mode of In3+. (c) Ball and stick and (d) space filling representations of the 3D structure of 1. The H atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: The H3L2 ligand with only different carboxyl positions () was used to replace H3L1 to react with In­(NO3)3 in a DMF solution, resulting in colorless block crystals of 2. Structural analysis reveals that 2 crystallizes in a monoclinic crystal system and C2/c space group (Table S1). In one crystallographic asymmetric unit, there is one L2 ligand, one In3+ ion, and one acetic acid. As shown in a, the In3+ centers in 2 are all in a heptacoordinated environment completed by six carboxylate oxygen atoms and a pyridine N atom. Thus, each In3+ is connected with three L2 ligands, forming a seven-coordinated environment completed by two oxygen atoms from two monodentately coordinated carboxylate groups, four oxygen atoms from two bidentate-chelate carboxylate groups, and an N donor, and each L2 ligand is coordinated with three In3+ ions, resulting in a (3,3)-connected 2D layerlike structure (b). As shown in d, the acetate ligands chelate the In centers on both sides of the layer to prevent further extension of the 2D layer along the a axis.
elements.clean_text: The H3L2 ligand with only different carboxyl positions () was used to replace H3L1 to react with In(NO3)3 in a DMF solution, resulting in colorless block crystals of 2. Structural analysis reveals that 2 crystallizes in a monoclinic crystal system and C2/c space group (Table S1). In one crystallographic asymmetric unit, there is one L2 ligand, one In3+ ion, and one acetic acid. As shown in a, the In3+ centers in 2 are all in a heptacoordinated environment completed by six carboxylate oxygen atoms and a pyridine N atom. Thus, each In3+ is connected with three L2 ligands, forming a seven-coordinated environment completed by two oxygen atoms from two monodentately coordinated carboxylate groups, four oxygen atoms from two bidentate-chelate carboxylate groups, and an N donor, and each L2 ligand is coordinated with three In3+ ions, resulting in a (3,3)-connected 2D layerlike structure (b). As shown in d, the acetate ligands chelate the In centers on both sides of the layer to prevent further extension of the 2D layer along the a axis.

elements.content: (a) Coordination mode of In3+ in 2. (b) 2D layer in 2 along the a axis. (c) Ball and stick representation of the 3D supramolecular structure of 2 along the c axis. (d) 2D layer in 2 viewed along the c axis. The H atoms are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Coordination mode of In3+ in 2. (b) 2D layer in 2 along the a axis. (c) Ball and stick representation of the 3D supramolecular structure of 2 along the c axis. (d) 2D layer in 2 viewed along the c axis. The H atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: Further, these layers are fused together via the electrostatic interactions into a 3D supramolecular framework (Figure S5), possessing two kinds of channels A′ and B′ with sizes of 5.25 × 9.69 and 4.29 × 8.66 Å2, respectively (c and Figure S6). In pore A′ , abundant uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen atoms reside in the channel, resulting in a hydrophilic surface of channel. As shown in c, d, there is another channel A′ in 2 with the size of 4.29 × 8.66 Å2. In the synthesis of 2, the acetic acid acts not only as a pH value adjuster but also as the chelate ligand in constructing a 2D layerlike structure. More importantly, it could be found that the change of carboxyl position in 3-phenylpyridine has an important effect on the final structure of the In-based MOFs. A detailed structural analysis indicates that the coordination of N to the In3+ center in 2 is achieved by regulating carboxyl sites in the 3-phenylpyridine ligand, thus increasing the stability of the In-based MOF.
elements.clean_text: Further, these layers are fused together via the electrostatic interactions into a 3D supramolecular framework (Figure S5), possessing two kinds of channels A' and B' with sizes of 5.25 × 9.69 and 4.29 × 8.66 Å2, respectively (c and Figure S6). In pore A' , abundant uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen atoms reside in the channel, resulting in a hydrophilic surface of channel. As shown in c, d, there is another channel A' in 2 with the size of 4.29 × 8.66 Å2. In the synthesis of 2, the acetic acid acts not only as a pH value adjuster but also as the chelate ligand in constructing a 2D layerlike structure. More importantly, it could be found that the change of carboxyl position in 3-phenylpyridine has an important effect on the final structure of the In-based MOFs. A detailed structural analysis indicates that the coordination of N to the In3+ center in 2 is achieved by regulating carboxyl sites in the 3-phenylpyridine ligand, thus increasing the stability of the In-based MOF.

elements.content: (a) Ball and stick and (b) space filling representations of 2 along the c axis. (c, d) structure of 2 showing the channel B′ with a size of 4.29 × 8.66 Å2. The H atoms are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Ball and stick and (b) space filling representations of 2 along the c axis. (c, d) structure of 2 showing the channel B' with a size of 4.29 × 8.66 Å2. The H atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: In order to verify the phase purity of as-synthesized 1 and 2, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were carried out on these two compounds. The PXRD patterns of the freshly prepared 1 and 2 matched well with their simulated PXRD patterns simulated from single-crystal data, indicating the phase purity of the bulk products (). Further, 1 and 2 were exposed to the air and doped into MeOH, which has been widely used as an exchanging solvent to replace guest molecules in the channels of MOFs for absorption measurements. As shown in a, the diffraction peaks in the PXRD of 1 completely disappeared if the sample was exposed to the air or soaked in MeOH for 24 h, revealing the full collapse of the framework of 1. For 2, the PXRD patterns of samples exposed to the air for 24 h, soaked in MeOH for 24 h, and activated for gas sorption (b) are similar to the simulated pattern, which can confirm the stability of the framework of 1 in the air and the MeOH solvent. This result also reveals that the formation of In–N bonds helps to enhance the stability of the In-based MOFs, which can be further used for gas absorption and separation.
elements.clean_text:
Stability

In order to verify the phase purity of as-synthesized 1 and 2, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were carried out on these two compounds. The PXRD patterns of the freshly prepared 1 and 2 matched well with their simulated PXRD patterns simulated from single-crystal data, indicating the phase purity of the bulk products (). Further, 1 and 2 were exposed to the air and doped into MeOH, which has been widely used as an exchanging solvent to replace guest molecules in the channels of MOFs for absorption measurements. As shown in a, the diffraction peaks in the PXRD of 1 completely disappeared if the sample was exposed to the air or soaked in MeOH for 24 h, revealing the full collapse of the framework of 1. For 2, the PXRD patterns of samples exposed to the air for 24 h, soaked in MeOH for 24 h, and activated for gas sorption (b) are similar to the simulated pattern, which can confirm the stability of the framework of 1 in the air and the MeOH solvent. This result also reveals that the formation of In-N bonds helps to enhance the stability of the In-based MOFs, which can be further used for gas absorption and separation.

elements.content: (a) PXRD patterns of 1 of the simulated and as-synthesized samples and samples exposed to the air or soaked in MeOH for 24 h. (b) PXRD patterns of 2 of the simulated and as-synthesized samples, samples exposed to the air or soaked in MeOH for 24 h, samples after adsorption experiments, and the activated samples (pretreated three times with MeOH and subsequently evacuated under vacuum).
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) PXRD patterns of 1 of the simulated and as-synthesized samples and samples exposed to the air or soaked in MeOH for 24 h. (b) PXRD patterns of 2 of the simulated and as-synthesized samples, samples exposed to the air or soaked in MeOH for 24 h, samples after adsorption experiments, and the activated samples (pretreated three times with MeOH and subsequently evacuated under vacuum).

elements.content: The thermal behavior of 1 and 2 was evaluated by TGA under an N2 flow with a ramp rate of 10 °C/min from 35 to 800 °C. For compound 1, the TG curve presents two weight losses. The first step is associated with the elimination of entrapped organic countercations [CH3NH2CH3]+ with a weight loss of ca. 10.1% in the temperature regime of 201–264 °C (calcd 8.53%), and the other weight loss with a temperature above 275 °C belongs to the collapse of the skeleton and the loss of the linking ligands. For 2, there are three weight losses appearing in the TGA curve. The initial weight loss of ca. 4.03% is attributed to the release of lattice water molecules at temperatures of 35–117 °C (calcd 1.73%); then loss of [(CH3)2NH2]+ and [(CH3)3NH]+ (ca. 11.6%) begins with an increase in the temperature to around 214 °C (calcd 10.20%), and the last weight loss starts at a temperature above 350 °C, corresponding to the degradation of the framework (Figure S8).
elements.clean_text: The thermal behavior of 1 and 2 was evaluated by TGA under an N2 flow with a ramp rate of 10 °C/min from 35 to 800 °C. For compound 1, the TG curve presents two weight losses. The first step is associated with the elimination of entrapped organic countercations [CH3NH2CH3]+ with a weight loss of ca. 10.1% in the temperature regime of 201-264 °C (calcd 8.53%), and the other weight loss with a temperature above 275 °C belongs to the collapse of the skeleton and the loss of the linking ligands. For 2, there are three weight losses appearing in the TGA curve. The initial weight loss of ca. 4.03% is attributed to the release of lattice water molecules at temperatures of 35-117 °C (calcd 1.73%); then loss of [(CH3)2NH2]+ and [(CH3)3NH]+ (ca. 11.6%) begins with an increase in the temperature to around 214 °C (calcd 10.20%), and the last weight loss starts at a temperature above 350 °C, corresponding to the degradation of the framework (Figure S8).

elements.content: CO2 and N2 are the main components of flue gas, which is caused by burning coal, oil, and other fossil fuels. Capturing CO2 from existing emission sources will greatly contribute to environmental protection. In this work, N2 adsorption at 77 K and CO2 adsorption (at 273 and 298 K) experiments were conducted to verify the stability and porosity of compounds 1 and 2. The samples were pretreated three times with MeOH (once for 24 h) and subsequently evacuated under vacuum at 100 °C for 12 h. It could be found that the framework of 1 collapsed after being activated, which was confirmed by an XRD analysis (a). For 2, it was still intact after being activated, indicating its potential suitability for gas sorption and separation. As shown in a, N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms of compound 2 reveal that the N2 uptake of 2 is only 4.73 cm3/g at 77 K at a relative pressure of P/P 0 = 1. For CO2, the saturated CO2 uptake can reach 12.6 cm3/g at 273 K with a relative pressure (P/P 0) approaching 1.0. It is worth mentioning that compound 2 shows a much higher volumetric uptake of CO2 under ambient conditions in comparison to that of N2 at a much lower temperature of 77 K, indicating an excellent adsorption selectivity for CO2 over N2.
elements.clean_text:
Gas Sorption Properties

CO2 and N2 are the main components of flue gas, which is caused by burning coal, oil, and other fossil fuels. Capturing CO2 from existing emission sources will greatly contribute to environmental protection. In this work, N2 adsorption at 77 K and CO2 adsorption (at 273 and 298 K) experiments were conducted to verify the stability and porosity of compounds 1 and 2. The samples were pretreated three times with MeOH (once for 24 h) and subsequently evacuated under vacuum at 100 °C for 12 h. It could be found that the framework of 1 collapsed after being activated, which was confirmed by an XRD analysis (a). For 2, it was still intact after being activated, indicating its potential suitability for gas sorption and separation. As shown in a, N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms of compound 2 reveal that the N2 uptake of 2 is only 4.73 cm3/g at 77 K at a relative pressure of P/P 0 = 1. For CO2, the saturated CO2 uptake can reach 12.6 cm3/g at 273 K with a relative pressure (P/P 0) approaching 1.0. It is worth mentioning that compound 2 shows a much higher volumetric uptake of CO2 under ambient conditions in comparison to that of N2 at a much lower temperature of 77 K, indicating an excellent adsorption selectivity for CO2 over N2.

elements.content: (a) N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms of 2 recorded at 77 K. (b) CO2 adsorption and desorption isotherms of 2 recorded at 273 and 298 K. (c) Comparison of the adsorption and desorption isotherms of CO2 at 273 K and N2 at 77 K.
elements.clean_text: 5  (a) N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms of 2 recorded at 77 K. (b) CO2 adsorption and desorption isotherms of 2 recorded at 273 and 298 K. (c) Comparison of the adsorption and desorption isotherms of CO2 at 273 K and N2 at 77 K.

elements.content: Two new In-based framework materials were designed and synthesized by the reaction of pyridine polycarboxylates and indium ions. A detailed study indicates that the coordination of N to the In3+ center in 2 is achieved by regulating the carboxyl sites in 3-phenylpyridine, thus dramatically increasing the stability of the In-based MOF. Although the coordination of N and acetate ligands to In3+ promotes the conversion of the 3D framework of 1 into the supramolecular structure of 2, the supramolecular structure of 2 is more stable in air and methanol in comparison to the 3D framework of 1. Thus, compound 2 could be used as a stable adsorbent to selectively capture CO2 from a CO2/N2 mixture, while compound 1 broke down sharply in air and the exchanging solvent methanol. This work may shed light on the design and synthesis of other MOF materials with high-valence TM centers and N-donors to improve their stability.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Two new In-based framework materials were designed and synthesized by the reaction of pyridine polycarboxylates and indium ions. A detailed study indicates that the coordination of N to the In3+ center in 2 is achieved by regulating the carboxyl sites in 3-phenylpyridine, thus dramatically increasing the stability of the In-based MOF. Although the coordination of N and acetate ligands to In3+ promotes the conversion of the 3D framework of 1 into the supramolecular structure of 2, the supramolecular structure of 2 is more stable in air and methanol in comparison to the 3D framework of 1. Thus, compound 2 could be used as a stable adsorbent to selectively capture CO2 from a CO2/N2 mixture, while compound 1 broke down sharply in air and the exchanging solvent methanol. This work may shed light on the design and synthesis of other MOF materials with high-valence TM centers and N-donors to improve their stability.

cln_elements.content:
H3L1 (10 mg, 0.03 mmol) and In­(NO3)3 ·4H2O (11 mg, 0.03 mmol) were added to a DMF (2 mL) solution containing glacial acetic acid (100 μL). Then, the mixture was stirred for 1/2 h at room temperature and placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. Subsequently, the solution was heated at 150 °C and maintained at that temperature for 72 h. Next, the mixture was slowly cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C h–1. Colorless crystals were harvested by centrifugation in a yield of 42% based on In. IR (KBr pellet) for 1: ν 1620 (s), 1360 (s), 1300 (w), 1246 (s), 1047 (w), 1019 (s), 938 (m), 863 (m), 841 (m), 783 (s), 721 (s), 699 (s), 663 (m), 442 (m) cm–1.

Synthesis of In<sub>2</sub>L<sup>2</sup> <sub>2</sub>(CH<sub>3</sub>COO)<sub>2</sub>·(CH<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>NH<sub>2</sub>·(CH<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub>NH·H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>2</bold>)

H3L2 (8 mg, 0.028 mmol) and In­(NO3)3 ·4H2O (20 mg, 0.053 mmol) were added to a DMF (2 mL) solution containing glacial acetic acid (200 μL); this mixture was stirred for 1/2 h at room temperature and placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. After it was heated at 130 °C for 72 h, the mixture was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C h–1. Colorless block crystals were harvested in a yield of 73% based on In. IR (KBr pellet) for 2: ν 1667 (s), 1367 (s), 1255 (w), 1097 (m), 1026 (w), 908 (w), 778 (s), 750 (w), 704 (m), 662 (m), 450 (m) cm–1.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis of In3L1 4⋅(CH3NH2CH3)3 (1)

H3L1 (10 mg, 0.03 mmol) and In(NO3)3 ⋅4H2O (11 mg, 0.03 mmol) were added to a DMF (2 mL) solution containing glacial acetic acid (100 μL). Then, the mixture was stirred for 1/2 h at room temperature and placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. Subsequently, the solution was heated at 150 °C and maintained at that temperature for 72 h. Next, the mixture was slowly cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C h-1. Colorless crystals were harvested by centrifugation in a yield of 42% based on In. IR (KBr pellet) for 1: ν 1620 (s), 1360 (s), 1300 (w), 1246 (s), 1047 (w), 1019 (s), 938 (m), 863 (m), 841 (m), 783 (s), 721 (s), 699 (s), 663 (m), 442 (m) cm-1.

Synthesis of In2L2 2(CH3COO)2⋅(CH3)2NH2⋅(CH3)3NH⋅H2O (2)

H3L2 (8 mg, 0.028 mmol) and In(NO3)3 ⋅4H2O (20 mg, 0.053 mmol) were added to a DMF (2 mL) solution containing glacial acetic acid (200 μL); this mixture was stirred for 1/2 h at room temperature and placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. After it was heated at 130 °C for 72 h, the mixture was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C h-1. Colorless block crystals were harvested in a yield of 73% based on In. IR (KBr pellet) for 2: ν 1667 (s), 1367 (s), 1255 (w), 1097 (m), 1026 (w), 908 (w), 778 (s), 750 (w), 704 (m), 662 (m), 450 (m) cm-1.

cln_elements.content:
The thermal behavior of 1 and 2 was evaluated by TGA under an N2 flow with a ramp rate of 10 °C/min from 35 to 800 °C. For compound 1, the TG curve presents two weight losses. The first step is associated with the elimination of entrapped organic countercations [CH3NH2CH3]+ with a weight loss of ca. 10.1% in the temperature regime of 201–264 °C (calcd 8.53%), and the other weight loss with a temperature above 275 °C belongs to the collapse of the skeleton and the loss of the linking ligands. For 2, there are three weight losses appearing in the TGA curve. The initial weight loss of ca. 4.03% is attributed to the release of lattice water molecules at temperatures of 35–117 °C (calcd 1.73%); then loss of [(CH3)2NH2]+ and [(CH3)3NH]+ (ca. 11.6%) begins with an increase in the temperature to around 214 °C (calcd 10.20%), and the last weight loss starts at a temperature above 350 °C, corresponding to the degradation of the framework (Figure S8).

Gas Sorption Properties

CO2 and N2 are the main components of flue gas, which is caused by burning coal, oil, and other fossil fuels. Capturing CO2 from existing emission sources will greatly contribute to environmental protection. In this work, N2 adsorption at 77 K and CO2 adsorption (at 273 and 298 K) experiments were conducted to verify the stability and porosity of compounds 1 and 2. The samples were pretreated three times with MeOH (once for 24 h) and subsequently evacuated under vacuum at 100 °C for 12 h. It could be found that the framework of 1 collapsed after being activated, which was confirmed by an XRD analysis (a). For 2, it was still intact after being activated, indicating its potential suitability for gas sorption and separation. As shown in a, N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms of compound 2 reveal that the N2 uptake of 2 is only 4.73 cm3/g at 77 K at a relative pressure of P/P 0 = 1. For CO2, the saturated CO2 uptake can reach 12.6 cm3/g at 273 K with a relative pressure (P/P 0) approaching 1.0. It is worth mentioning that compound 2 shows a much higher volumetric uptake of CO2 under ambient conditions in comparison to that of N2 at a much lower temperature of 77 K, indicating an excellent adsorption selectivity for CO2 over N2.

The thermal behavior of 1 and 2 was evaluated by TGA under an N2 flow with a ramp rate of 10 °C/min from 35 to 800 °C. For compound 1, the TG curve presents two weight losses. The first step is associated with the elimination of entrapped organic countercations [CH3NH2CH3]+ with a weight loss of ca. 10.1% in the temperature regime of 201-264 °C (calcd 8.53%), and the other weight loss with a temperature above 275 °C belongs to the collapse of the skeleton and the loss of the linking ligands. For 2, there are three weight losses appearing in the TGA curve. The initial weight loss of ca. 4.03% is attributed to the release of lattice water molecules at temperatures of 35-117 °C (calcd 1.73%); then loss of [(CH3)2NH2]+ and [(CH3)3NH]+ (ca. 11.6%) begins with an increase in the temperature to around 214 °C (calcd 10.20%), and the last weight loss starts at a temperature above 350 °C, corresponding to the degradation of the framework (Figure S8).

Gas Sorption Properties

CO2 and N2 are the main components of flue gas, which is caused by burning coal, oil, and other fossil fuels. Capturing CO2 from existing emission sources will greatly contribute to environmental protection. In this work, N2 adsorption at 77 K and CO2 adsorption (at 273 and 298 K) experiments were conducted to verify the stability and porosity of compounds 1 and 2. The samples were pretreated three times with MeOH (once for 24 h) and subsequently evacuated under vacuum at 100 °C for 12 h. It could be found that the framework of 1 collapsed after being activated, which was confirmed by an XRD analysis (a). For 2, it was still intact after being activated, indicating its potential suitability for gas sorption and separation. As shown in a, N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms of compound 2 reveal that the N2 uptake of 2 is only 4.73 cm3/g at 77 K at a relative pressure of P/P 0 = 1. For CO2, the saturated CO2 uptake can reach 12.6 cm3/g at 273 K with a relative pressure (P/P 0) approaching 1.0. It is worth mentioning that compound 2 shows a much higher volumetric uptake of CO2 under ambient conditions in comparison to that of N2 at a much lower temperature of 77 K, indicating an excellent adsorption selectivity for CO2 over N2.

metadata.title:
Nitrogen Coordination To Dramatically Enhance the Stability of In-MOF for Selectively
Capturing CO2 from a CO2/N2 Mixture
